lightning-fast Series A (that was 3 years in the making)"},"content":{"rendered":"<div class=\"article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n<div class=\"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t<div class=\"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-name\">Nathan Beckord<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<span class=\"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/foundersuite\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<svg class=\"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\t<title>Share on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t<path d=\"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tNathan Beckord is CEO of <a href=\"http:\/\/foundersuite.com\/\">Foundersuite.com<\/a>, a software platform for raising capital and managing investors that has helped entrepreneurs raise over $2 billion since 2016. He is also the host of <a href=\"https:\/\/soundcloud.com\/user-2586856\/ep-121-how-i-raised-it-with-aydin-mirzaee-of-fellowapp\">Foundersuite\u2019s How I Raised It<\/a> podcast.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t\t<div class=\"contributor-byline__more-articles\">\n\t\t<span class=\"more-articles-title\">More posts by this contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<ul class=\"more-articles-list\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/23\/founders-seeking-their-first-check-need-a-fundraising-sales-funnel\/\">Founders seeking their first check need a fundraising sales funnel<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<li><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/09\/23\/fundraising-lessons-from-david-rogier-of-masterclass\/\">Fundraising lessons from David Rogier of MasterClass<\/a><\/li>\n\t\t\t\t\t<\/ul>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Christine Tao runs<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.soundingboardinc.com\/\"> Sounding Board<\/a>, a business founded in 2016 that offers executive coaching services to leaders at major companies like Kraft and Heinz. But not long ago, she was the one in need of a coach.<\/p>\n<p>But prior to that, Tao found herself in a new high-powered position at the mobile advertising company Tapjoy. Although she had plenty of sales experience, she was now working in an executive role leading the company&#8217;s entire sales staff. It was a tough learning curve. But the company&#8217;s board paired her with an executive coach, Lori Mazan, who ultimately helped Tao succeed.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;That really had a profound impact, not just on my professional development, but my personal development as well,&#8221; Tao said.<\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--left\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tShow investors that you&#8217;re committed to following through. That makes all the difference.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<p>Later on, Tao and Mazan teamed up to launch Sounding Board, a service with a proprietary algorithm that matches participants with coaches. Its capabilities-driven model can even measure the impact of the coaching.<\/p>\n<p>At the beginning, Tao didn&#8217;t have many resources. Ultimately, she raised $15 million in a pre-seed and Series A round. An impressive group of investors got in on the action, including<a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/roybahat\"> Roy Bahat of Bloomberg Beta<\/a>,<a href=\"https:\/\/precursorvc.com\/team_member\/charles-hudson\/\"> Charles Hudson of Precursor Ventures<\/a> and<a href=\"https:\/\/www.canaan.com\/team\/maha-ibrahim\"> Maha Ibrahim of Canaan<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>On<a href=\"https:\/\/blog.foundersuite.com\/how-i-raised-it-with-christine-tao-of-sounding-board\/\"> an episode of the \u201cHow I Raised It\u201d podcast<\/a>, Tao talked about raising money quickly, honing your strategy and getting back on your feet after all you hear is &#8220;no.&#8221;<\/p>\n<h2>Start out scrappy<\/h2>\n<p>From the very beginning, Tao had big ideas.<\/p>\n<p>She wanted to make coaching accessible to all sorts of executive leaders. The service wouldn&#8217;t just be for correcting bad behavior, as coaching had been in the past, but about helping executives grow and develop so that they could lead their businesses with their best foot forward. Tao also aimed to make coaching available through remote technology.<\/p>\n<p>The problem was, Tao didn&#8217;t quite have the resources to get started. Initially, turning those ideas into a functioning business seemed about as realistic as climbing Mount Everest.<\/p>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>It took Christine Tao, founder of Sounding Board, just over three years to recognize the value of executive coaching and get her company to a Series A. Here&#8217;s how she did Board","slug":"sounding-board","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576608491"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576608491"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576608491"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576608491"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576608491"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[{"id":576796353,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/extracrunch\/fundraising\/","name":"Fundraising","slug":"fundraising","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796353"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796353"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2127453,"date":"2021-03-19T07:16:45","date_gmt":"2021-03-19T14:16:45","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2127453"},"modified":"2021-03-19T10:32:40","modified_gmt":"2021-03-19T17:32:40","slug":"spacex-nears-final-assembly-of-its-first-massive-testing-rocket-booster-for-starship","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/spacex-nears-final-assembly-of-its-first-massive-testing-rocket-booster-for-starship\/","title":{"rendered":"SpaceX nears final assembly of its first massive testing rocket booster for Starship"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">SpaceX has completed what&#8217;s known as the &#8220;stacking&#8221; of its first Super Heavy prototype, the extremely large next-generation first-stage rocket booster that it will eventually use to propel its Starship spacecraft to orbit and beyond. The Super Heavy Booster is about 220 feet tall \u2014 which is roughly the wingspan of a Boeing 747, or a bit taller than the Cinderella Castle at Walt Disney World in Florida.<\/p>\n<p>That&#8217;s without Starship on top, which will add around another 160 feet. Super Heavy will undergo its own testing prior to flying with Starship, however, and a lot of that will be focused on assuring its fuel tanks can handle the pressurization and extreme temperatures required for keeping all that ignitable material stable prior to when the engines actually fire.<\/p>\n<p>Super Heavy uses the same engines as Starship \u2014 Raptor engines, to be specific, which SpaceX created new for this generation of launch vehicle. The final version will have a total of 28 Raptor engines, but this first prototype will likely be outfitted with far fewer, and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk has confirmed that it&#8217;ll also remain grounded, as it&#8217;s intended to be used only for testing things like build and transportation mechanics.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Yes, Booster 1 is a production pathfinder, figuring out how to build &amp; transport 70 meter tall stage. Booster 2 will fly.<\/p>\n<p>&mdash; Elon Musk (@elonmusk) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1372695421487824903?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 18, 2021<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>He did say the next prototype will fly, and while he isn&#8217;t always accurate about timelines, the Starship upper stage (i.e., the one that looks like a big grain silo with fins) is progressing quickly in its development, including with a recent test flight that <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/03\/spacexs-starship-prototype-flies-to-32000-feet-and-sticks-the-landing-in-third-flight-test\/\">ended with a near-perfect landing<\/a> \u2014 minus the subsequent explosion that took out the prototype rocket entirely a few minutes after it had touched down successfully.<\/p>\n<p>Musk clearly wants to move fast with Starship and Super Heavy, in part because of ambitious goals it has of serving as a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/30\/spacex-blue-origin-and-dynetics-will-build-human-lunar-landers-for-nasas-next-trip-back-to-the-moon\/\">provider to NASA for future human lunar landing missions as part of the Artemis program<\/a>, and also because it&#8217;s still planning to fly the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/02\/spacexs-first-paying-moon-flight-customer-wants-to-give-away-eight-seats-aboard-his-spaceship\/\">first commercial tourist flight of a Starship in just two short years in 2023<\/a>.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"a3sJao6PhN\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/20\/spacexs-spin-out-startups-are-helping-build-las-startup-ecosystem\/\">SpaceX alumni are helping build LA&#8217;s startup ecosystem<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;SpaceX alumni are helping build LA&#8217;s startup ecosystem&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/20\/spacexs-spin-out-startups-are-helping-build-las-startup-ecosystem\/embed\/#?secret=a3sJao6PhN\" data-secret=\"a3sJao6PhN\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>SpaceX has completed what&#8217;s known as the &#8220;stacking&#8221; of its first Super Heavy prototype, the extremely large next-generation first-stage rocket booster that it will eventually use to propel its Starship spacecraft to orbit and beyond. The Super Heavy Booster is about 220 feet tall \u2014 which is roughly the wingspan of a Boeing 747, or /wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449560590"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449560590"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449560590"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":371748,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/spacex\/","name":"SpaceX","slug":"spacex","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/371748"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=371748"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=371748"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=371748"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=371748"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576625208,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/spacex-starship\/","name":"spacex starship","slug":"spacex-starship","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576625208"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576625208"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576625208"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576625208"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576625208"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449551625,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/starship\/","name":"Starship","slug":"starship","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449551625"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449551625"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449551625"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449551625"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449551625"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576625207,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/super-heavy\/","name":"super heavy","slug":"super-heavy","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576625207"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576625207"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576625207"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576625207"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576625207"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2127411,"date":"2021-03-19T12:01:46","date_gmt":"2021-03-19T19:01:46","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2127411"},"modified":"2021-03-19T12:28:15","modified_gmt":"2021-03-19T19:28:15","slug":"sidekick-browser-wants-to-be-a-productivity-honed-work-os-on-chromium","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/sidekick-browser-wants-to-be-a-productivity-honed-work-os-on-chromium\/","title":{"rendered":"Sidekick Browser wants to be a productivity-honed &#8216;work OS&#8217; on Chromium"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The paradox of connected computing is how much information is made available to us in just a few clicks or taps &#8212; but also how this ocean of available data can overwhelm and lap over a particular bit of intel the moment we need to lay our fingers back on it.<\/p>\n<p>Fire up a web browser and it&#8217;s hard to deny it&#8217;s the best of times for knowledge work. Yet working across multiple browser tabs and windows can feel like the friction-filled, frustrating worst.<\/p>\n<p>This is the problem <a href=\"https:\/\/www.meetsidekick.com\">Sidekick Browser<\/a> is taking aim at by adding a productivity-focused layer atop Chromium that it bills as a &#8220;work OS&#8221;.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Multiple tab hell? Sidekick&#8217;s answer is to let you work from inside apps that live in the browser, rather than scattered across multiple windows and tabs.<\/p>\n<p>Apps like Slack and Skype and WhatsApp can be pinned in the sidebar in a vertical stack where you can easily find and switch between them. It also has support for multiple logins, granular notification controls and the ability to search across all these third-party apps (it offers &#8220;hundreds&#8221; currently but says users can add custom adds &#8220;which would function just like a bookmark&#8221;) right from the browser.<\/p>\n<p>And for all those tabs you open up every time you go down an internet browsing rabbit hole, Sidekick offers a Sessions feature that lets you save them as a collective bundle for easy filing away &#8212; with ofc the ability to reopen and revisit again at a later click.<\/p>\n<p>The built-in search also spans these Sessions so there&#8217;s no need to manually scroll back through the browser&#8217;s search history to try to track down where exactly it was you saw that reference to that randomly relevant bit of intel you breezed across one online day.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"2RnIl81BiG\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/03\/browsers-are-interesting-again\/\">Browsers are interesting again<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Browsers are interesting again&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/03\/browsers-are-interesting-again\/embed\/#?secret=2RnIl81BiG\" data-secret=\"2RnIl81BiG\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;Search across all your apps, tabs and workspaces in seconds,&#8221; is Sidekick&#8217;s alternative fix.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s also tackling productivity on the technical side &#8212; taking aim at browser-based lag with an &#8220;AI based tab suspension&#8221; feature that&#8217;s designed to improve on how Google&#8217;s Chrome browser hogs RAM by predicting which tabs the user is not going to use and dumping them from memory.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Sidekick is the fastest browser built especially for work,&#8221; is its elevator-pitchy promise.<\/p>\n<p>Collaboration is another core focus with features intended to help knowledge working teams be more productive as a unit; offering stuff like team role provisioning and custom workspaces to support different Session, app Sidebar and tabs set-ups, such as for a project or client.<\/p>\n<p>There&#8217;s also remote configuration tools for device security; a baked-in password manager for collaborative convenience to support teams needing to share passwords; and an embedded video chat platform so you can do team chats right from the exact same browser-based workspace you&#8217;re all using.<\/p>\n<p>Sidekick comes with its own ad blocker and anti-fingerprinting tech too &#8212; for a stated privacy purpose but also for an extra speed bump (i.e. via better page load times).<\/p>\n<p>Also on privacy, the startup&#8217;s very public promise is &#8220;we&#8217;ll never sell your data&#8221; (and it further specifies this includes &#8220;searches, browsing history, or any personal information&#8221;).<\/p>\n<p>The business model is SaaS and B2C for now, but Sidekick has designs on B2B &#8212; touting a pipeline of business-friendly features coming down the line.<\/p>\n<p>And &#8212; yes, before you ask &#8212; Chrome extensions are supported.<\/p>\n<p>Sidekick is announcing $2 million in seed funding led by KPCB &#8212; along with Remote First Capital and other angel investors.<\/p>\n<p>Founder Dmitry Pushkarev has played and won at the startup game before, in some very different areas &#8212; having founded a DNA sequencing company (Moleculo) back in 2011, which was quickly acquired by Illumina.<\/p>\n<p>Then in 2013 he left to found another business, ClusterK &#8212; focused on optimizing cloud computing resources across multiple cloud providers &#8212; which was acquired by Amazon in 2016, where Pushkarev stayed for a couple of years before getting the founder itch again.<\/p>\n<p>A stint as entrepreneur in residence (EIR) at Kleiner Perkins investigating the future of work was where the germ of the idea for Sidekick was born.<\/p>\n<p>The tool grabbed some early eyeballs a few months ago <a href=\"https:\/\/www.producthunt.com\/posts\/sidekick-browser\">via Product Hunt<\/a> &#8212; where Chris Messina was among its early fans, lauding the team for shaking up the browser space by combining &#8220;so many components that are essential to finding productivity as a modern knowledge worker!&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>Though Pushkarev was careful to course-correct Messina that it&#8217;s not building a full-fat browser to challenge Chrome itself (or any other internet browser).<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We do not intend to compete with browsers, they are a great choice for browsing,&#8221; he wrote. &#8220;Our goal is improve the browsing experience for work and productivity &#8212; something that, regretfully, browsers cannot do.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The San Francisco-based startup says it&#8217;s now being used by teams at companies including Microsoft, Dropbox, Slack and Lyft. It has around 30,000 users at this point a few months after its November 2020 launch, per Pushkarev, who says the team is mostly focused on product (&#8220;activation, retention, virality&#8221;) at this early stage.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The typical user is a knowledge worker &#8212; product managers, engineers, marketers, a fair number of students. Basically, prosumers who don&#8217;t just browse online, but do productive work and utilize communication tools,&#8221; he tells TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;During my EIR at KPCB, we thought a lot about the future of work, and one striking aspect of it is that today knowledge workers spend most of their time working in Browsers &#8212; a tool designed for Browsing,&#8221; he goes on, explaining the genesis of the idea for Sidekick.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;There are some important differences between how we browse and how we work, in particular &#8212; knowledge workers, spend more time working in web applications, with documents, using communications tools, accessing multiple accounts, and having to navigate a vast array of documents and projects. Unlike browsing &#8212; which is mostly search-based consumption of information.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Clearly, these are very different use cases, but companies who make browsers today have no ability to invest in making browser better for work due to their business model &#8212; they are paid by Google or Microsoft for searches, and any complication of the UX would mean that millions of users would turn to simpler browsers and they will lose search revenue.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We thought that it&#8217;s an unprecedented situation, where 200M professionals don\u2019t have access to professional tools, and that the industry is so heavily disincentivized to build those. As a result, we decided to change this and invent a new category of software &#8212; Browser for Work, or how we call it internally &#8212; a Work OS.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>So what type of work\/worker is Sidekick made for?\u00a0&#8220;Online work with Web applications, lots of documents, communication apps, multiple accounts, and different work streams. It&#8217;s designer for prosumers and wouldn&#8217;t be the best choice for just browsing &#8212; something that would be better served by other browsers,&#8221; he says.<\/p>\n<p>While the laser focus is work and productivity, Sidekick users can create multiple environments within the software &#8212; so could make other spaces more geared toward chilling out\/downtime, or other purposes than work too, for use at other times.<\/p>\n<p>While browsers do offer a variety of features like shortcuts and other elements aimed at increasing convenience, Pushkarev argues they simple can&#8217;t go as far as Sidekick intends to in honing a great work environment because their business model is too focused on search ads (in the case of Google Chrome) &#8212; or just because they need to be a more generalist tool for web browsing. Sidekick is therefore very much a &#8220;standalone business,&#8221; not just a nice set of enhancements any existing browser could make, in his view.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Unfortunately, extending other browsers is not a viable path here, one has to go deep inside Chrome codebase and re-think performance, memory optimization, security, support for multiple accounts, and privacy to build a comprehensive solution,&#8221; he says.<\/p>\n<p>One example of going above and beyond what a browser could or would do itself is the support it&#8217;s built for &#8220;hundreds&#8221; of third-party apps. &#8220;The reason we built this support is for better integrations &#8212; being able to display and control badges and notifications, integrate with our search, support multiple accounts and add helpful extensions,&#8221; he explains.<\/p>\n<p>He also points to the New Tab Page (shown in the feature image at the top of this post), which is due to launch for all users by the end of the month and which displays &#8220;all documents that work with organized according to type, with human-readable titles, and instant search across it&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Without deep integration with these apps we wouldn\u2019t be able to provide this experience and display barely usable browser history instead,&#8221; he notes.<\/p>\n<p>On the business model front, Pushkarev is confident that SaaS can work &#8212; and that Sidekick doesn&#8217;t have to monetize like other browsers do (i.e. &#8220;through data and searches&#8221;) &#8212; arguing:\u00a0&#8220;We are making a tool that saves hours to potentially millions of knowledge workers.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Another piece of the story is our <a href=\"https:\/\/www.meetsidekick.com\/how-it-works\">B2B business<\/a>, which we are building as we speak, but it&#8217;s still in early beta. In B2B, product browsers become a sort of company-provisioned remote workstations, that can be remotely configured and secured according to a role,&#8221; he adds.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;This is where the majority of our revenue comes from at the moment, but we are launching our first attempts at B2C monetization in March, by offering a subscription.&#8221;<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"bpfvaMX1wR\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/02\/everyone-has-an-opinion-on-the-27-7b-slack-acquisition\/\">Everyone has an opinion on the $27.7B Slack acquisition<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Everyone has an opinion on the $27.7B Slack acquisition&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/02\/everyone-has-an-opinion-on-the-27-7b-slack-acquisition\/embed\/#?secret=bpfvaMX1wR\" data-secret=\"bpfvaMX1wR\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Kp5SqYY8HT\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/29\/kpcb-has-already-blown-through-much-of-the-600-million-it-raised-last-year\/\">Kleiner Perkins has already blown through much of the $600 million it raised last year<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; but also how this ocean of available data can overwhelm and lap over a particular bit of intel the moment we need to lay our fingers back on it. Fire up a web tools","slug":"productivity-tools","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576865357"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576865357"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576865357"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576865357"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576865357"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576865358,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/sidekick-browser\/","name":"Sidekick Browser","slug":"sidekick-browser","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576865358"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576865358"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576865358"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576865358"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576865358"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2127724,"date":"2021-03-19T12:07:49","date_gmt":"2021-03-19T19:07:49","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2127724"},"modified":"2021-03-19T12:09:21","modified_gmt":"2021-03-19T19:09:21","slug":"facebook-showcases-wrist-worn-ar-interface-concept","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/facebook-showcases-wrist-worn-ar-interface-concept\/","title":{"rendered":"Facebook showcases wrist-worn AR interface concept"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Facebook\u2019s hardware strategy often looks pretty opaque from the outside. The company has done fairly well with Oculus sales amid pandemic demand. Even its Echo Show competitor Portal has seen a bump as people have been forced to socially distance. The company\u2019s smartphone partnership with HTC, meanwhile, fell flat eight or so years back.<\/p>\n<p>Earlier this year, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/facebook-plans-smartwatch-with-focus-on-messaging-health\">reports surfaced<\/a> that the company was working on its own Apple Watch competitor. The smartwatch was said to have a health focus, running on an open-source version of Android. That, of course, would mark an interesting alternative from Google\u2019s chosen wearOS.<\/p>\n<p>This week, the company highlighted <a href=\"https:\/\/about.fb.com\/news\/2021\/03\/inside-facebook-reality-labs-wrist-based-interaction-for-the-next-computing-platform\/\">another wrist-based wearable<\/a>. The specifics of the project don\u2019t line up super closely with earlier reports, which could well mean two separate projects. Facebook is a big company, after all.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden;\" src=\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/plugins\/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FTechAtFacebook%2Fvideos%2F1126949421469231%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=560\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"><\/iframe><\/p>\n<p>This particular project out of Facebook Reality Labs is more focused on providing an alternative computer interface. Specifically, it seems in line with the company\u2019s augmented reality efforts.<\/p>\n<p>Per yesterday\u2019s blog post:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>A separate device you could store in your pocket like a phone or a game controller adds a layer of friction between you and your environment. As we explored the possibilities, placing an input device at the wrist became the clear answer. The wrist is a traditional place to wear a watch, meaning it could reasonably fit into everyday life and social contexts. It\u2019s a comfortable location for all-day wear. It\u2019s located right next to the primary instruments you use to interact with the world \u2014 your hands. This proximity would allow us to bring the rich control capabilities of your hands into AR, enabling intuitive, powerful and satisfying interaction.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>I will say that, based on the information presented, this seems more conceptual. As in, this could be the key to offering more seamless control for some future augmented reality system. And even still, it\u2019s presented as a step on the way to a more deeply integrated human-computer solution. How deeply you want Facebook to integrate with your neurons is apparently a question we\u2019re all going to have to ask ourselves in the not too distant future.<\/p>\n<p><iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden;\" src=\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/plugins\/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FTechAtFacebook%2Fvideos%2F1146186389155473%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=560\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"><\/iframe><\/p>\n<p>This interface specifically is designed to use electromyography (EMG) sensors to interpret motor nerve signals and interact with the interface accordingly. The subject interestingly came up <a href=\"https:\/\/constine.substack.com\/p\/pressclub-with-mark-zuckerberg-daniel\">during a Clubhouse event<\/a> featuring Mark Zuckerberg last night. After Pebble founder\/YC partner Eric Migicovsky discussed experiences dealing with Apple for his own smartwatch startup, the Facebook CEO said the following:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>If you&#8217;re trying to build a watch, which we&#8217;re exploring as we talked about the wrist thing and I don&#8217;t want to call it a watch, but it&#8217;s the basic neural interfaces work that our Facebook reality labs team demoed some of our research about today. With the neural interface on the wrist, if you want that to integrate with the phone in any way, it&#8217;s just so much easier on Android than iOS. My guess is that this is an area where there probably should be a lot more focus. And I do think the private APIs are just something that makes it really difficult to have a healthy ecosystem.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>\u201cExploring\u201d seems like an operative word here. But it\u2019s always cool\/fascinating to see these projects in their early stages. Even if the promises might still seem a tad\u2026overzealous.<\/p>\n<p>EMG will eventually progress to richer controls. In AR, you\u2019ll be able to actually touch and move virtual UIs and objects, as you can see in this demo video. You\u2019ll also be able to control virtual objects at a distance. It\u2019s sort of like having a superpower like the Force.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"aWZcUonNsO\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/12\/will-apple-facebook-or-microsoft-be-the-future-of-augmented-reality\/\">Will Apple, Facebook or Microsoft be the future of augmented reality?<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Will Apple, Facebook or Microsoft be the future of augmented reality?&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/12\/will-apple-facebook-or-microsoft-be-the-future-of-augmented-reality\/embed\/#?secret=aWZcUonNsO\" data-secret=\"aWZcUonNsO\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"IiUrheTwBZ\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/19\/week-in-review-facebook-hardware-finds-pandemic-market-fit\/\">Week in Review: Facebook hardware finds pandemic market fit<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Week in Review: Facebook hardware finds pandemic market fit&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/19\/week-in-review-facebook-hardware-finds-pandemic-market-fit\/embed\/#?secret=IiUrheTwBZ\" data-secret=\"IiUrheTwBZ\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>&nbsp;<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Facebook\u2019s hardware strategy often looks pretty opaque from the outside. The company has done fairly well with Oculus sales amid pandemic demand. Even its Echo Show competitor Portal has seen a bump as people have been forced to socially distance. The company\u2019s smartphone partnership with HTC, meanwhile, fell flat eight or so years back. Earlier son\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=26895916"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=26895916"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=26895916"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2123733,"date":"2021-03-19T09:55:26","date_gmt":"2021-03-19T16:55:26","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2123733"},"modified":"2021-03-19T10:25:46","modified_gmt":"2021-03-19T17:25:46","slug":"attend-disrupt-2021-for-less-than-100","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/attend-disrupt-2021-for-less-than-100\/","title":{"rendered":"Attend Disrupt 2021 for less than $100"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">If three jam-packed days of TechCrunch <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-disrupt-2021\">Disrupt 2021<\/a>, the mother of all tech conferences that takes place on September 21-23, wasn\u2019t enough to get your startup motor running, listen up. You can attend the all-virtual <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-disrupt-2021\">TC Disrupt 2021<\/a> for less than a $100. Your eyes do not deceive. Read on!<\/p>\n<p>Right now, super early-bird pricing is in play for Founder, Innovator and Investor passes \u2014 and every single one sells for less than $100. But this largess won\u2019t last. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-disrupt-2021\/tickets\/\">Buy your pass to Disrupt 2021<\/a> before the super early-bird deadline expires on <strong>May 13, 11:59 pm (PST)<\/strong>.<\/p>\n<p>Let\u2019s talk about what Disrupt offers this year. In a word, plenty. In more words, opportunity, connection, networking, competition and a whole lot of experts downloading their knowledge to help you achieve your startup dreams.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Networking is a huge part of Disrupt, and you\u2019ll find multiple ways to make valuable connections. Whether they happen spontaneously in our virtual event platform (the chat is where it\u2019s at!) or curated meetups through CrunchMatch, our AI-powered platform, you\u2019ll meet smart, exciting people eager to share, collaborate and inspire.<\/p>\n<p>You\u2019ll hear from and engage with marquee speakers from the Disrupt Stage \u2014 stay ahead of the trends, learn how others overcame struggles you\u2019re facing and gain insight from expert analysis.<\/p>\n<p>Get your how-to on over at the Extra Crunch Stage where you engage in interactive sessions and get you\u2019re your burning questions answered on the spot. Take advantage of pitch deck teardowns or explore other expert-led sessions for actionable tips to help you better define your business and build a stronger startup.<\/p>\n<p>Join the Extra Crunch bunch. Disrupt passes include a free 3-month membership to Extra Crunch. We\u2019re talking exclusive content like IPO analysis, expert how-tos on monetization, strategy and growth and investor surveys. Boom, value added.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-disrupt-2021\/startup-alley\/\">Startup Alley<\/a> is back this year with new exposure opportunities for exhibitors \u2014 including a chance to participate in the elite <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-disrupt-2021\/startup-alley\/\">StartupAlley+<\/a>. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-disrupt-2021\/tickets\/\">Buy a Startup Alley Pass<\/a> and shine the influential Disrupt spotlight on your amazing company.<\/p>\n<p>This year, we\u2019re opening <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/startup-battlefield\/\">Startup Battlefield<\/a> to even more early-stage founders. With five semi-final rounds, it\u2019ll be our biggest, most exciting Startup Battlefield ever! Think you\u2019ve got what it takes to claim the title and the $100,000 prize? Applications for Startup Battlefield will open Q2 2021.<\/p>\n<p>Okay, we listed lots of reasons to attend Disrupt. Now hear why one of your own thinks Disrupt is an essential part of startup life.<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>\u201cDisrupt is laser focused on startups. I\u2019m just starting my own company and attending Disrupt was an incredible opportunity to connect with companies and learn from the best people in the industry.\u201d \u2014 Anirudh Murali, co-founder and CEO, Economize.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Don\u2019t miss your chance to attend Disrupt 2021 for less than $100. <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-disrupt-2021\/tickets\/\">Buy your pass<\/a> before that super early bird price expires on May 13 at 11:59 pm (PST). Batman wouldn\u2019t spend more than a Benjamin.<\/p>\n<p><em>Is your company interested in sponsoring or exhibiting at Disrupt 2021? Battlefield","url":"\/startup-battlefield","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1996941,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1996939,"order":6,"parent":0,"text":"Apply to our Startup Programs","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/pages\/?page_id=1617703","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1617703,"object":"page","type":"post_type","type_label":"Page","children":[]},{"id":2009102,"order":7,"parent":0,"text":"Contact Us","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/pages\/contact-us\/","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":672,"object":"page","type":"post_type","type_label":"Page","children":[]}],"include":[{"id":2029903,"order":1,"parent":0,"text":"Include Home","url":"\/include\/","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":2029903,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1601974,"order":2,"parent":0,"text":"Our Mission","url":"\/include\/mission-statement","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1601974,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1601975,"order":3,"parent":0,"text":"Office Hours","url":"\/include\/office-hours","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1601975,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]}],"video-hub":[{"id":1605165,"order":1,"parent":0,"text":"News","url":"\/shows\/tctv-news","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605165,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605168,"order":4,"parent":0,"text":"Reviews","url":"\/shows\/reviews","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605168,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605169,"order":5,"parent":0,"text":"Interviews","url":"\/shows\/interviews","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605169,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605170,"order":6,"parent":0,"text":"Apps","url":"\/shows\/apps","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605170,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605171,"order":7,"parent":0,"text":"Disrupt","url":"\/shows\/techcrunch-disrupt","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605171,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605172,"order":8,"parent":0,"text":"Battlefield","url":"\/shows\/techcrunch-battlefield","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605172,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605173,"order":9,"parent":0,"text":"Sessions","url":"\/shows\/tc-sessions","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605173,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605174,"order":10,"parent":0,"text":"Crunch Report","url":"\/shows\/crunch-report","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605174,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605175,"order":11,"parent":0,"text":"Judah vs the Machines","url":"\/shows\/judah-vs-the-machines","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605175,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605176,"order":12,"parent":0,"text":"Down Round","url":"\/shows\/down-round","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605176,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605177,"order":13,"parent":0,"text":"Trust Disrupted","url":"\/shows\/trust-disrupted","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605177,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605178,"order":14,"parent":0,"text":"Built in Brooklyn","url":"\/shows\/built-in-brooklyn","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605178,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605179,"order":15,"parent":0,"text":"Inside Jobs","url":"\/shows\/inside-jobs","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605179,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]},{"id":1605180,"order":16,"parent":0,"text":"TC Cribs","url":"\/shows\/tc-cribs","attr":"","target":"","classes":[""],"description":"","object_id":1605180,"object":"custom","type":"custom","type_label":"Custom Link","children":[]}]},"entities":{"posts":[{"id":2127248,"date":"2021-03-21T08:30:50","date_gmt":"2021-03-21T15:30:50","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2127248"},"modified":"2021-03-18T17:31:19","modified_gmt":"2021-03-19T00:31:19","slug":"the-debate-about-cryptocurrency-and-energy-consumption","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/21\/the-debate-about-cryptocurrency-and-energy-consumption\/","title":{"rendered":"The debate about cryptocurrency and energy consumption"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Energy consumption has become the latest flashpoint for cryptocurrency. Critics decry it as an energy hog while proponents hail it for being less intensive than the current global economy.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">One such critic, <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/digiconomist.net\/about\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">DigiEconomist<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> founder Alex de Vries, said he\u2019s \u201cnever seen anything that is as inefficient as bitcoin.\u201d\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">On the other side of the debate, research by <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/ark-invest.com\/articles\/analyst-research\/bitcoin-myths\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ARK Investment Management<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> found the Bitcoin ecosystem consumes less than 10% of the energy required for the traditional banking system. While it\u2019s true the banking system serves far more people, cryptocurrency is still maturing and, like any industry, the early infrastructure stage is particularly intensive.<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The cryptocurrency mining industry, which garnered almost <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/bitcoin-miners-saw-record-1-36b-revenue-in-february\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">$1.4 billion<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> in February 2021 alone, is not yet unusually terrible for the environment compared to other aspects of modern life in an industrialized society. Even de Vries told TechCrunch that if eco-conscious regulators \u201ctook all possible actions against Bitcoin, it\u2019s unlikely you\u2019d get all governments to go along with that\u201d mining regulation.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cIdeally, change comes from within,\u201d de Vries said, adding he hopes Bitcoin Core developers will alter the software to require less computational energy. \u201cI think Bitcoin consumes <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/digiconomist.net\/bitcoin-may-consume-as-much-energy-as-all-data-centers-globally\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">half <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">as much energy as all the world\u2019s <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/energyinnovation.org\/2020\/03\/17\/how-much-energy-do-data-centers-really-use\/#:~:text=The%20finding%20that%20global%20data,past%20decade%20(Figure%202).\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">data centers<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> at the moment.\u201d\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">According to the University of Cambridge\u2019s <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/cbeci.org\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">bitcoin electricity consumption index<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, bitcoin miners are expected to consume roughly 130 Terawatt-hours of energy (TWh), which is roughly <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/cbeci.org\/cbeci\/comparisons\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">0.6%<\/span><\/a> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">of global electricity consumption. This puts the bitcoin economy on par with the <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/us-crypto-currency-tesla-climate-insight\/elon-musk-wants-clean-power-but-teslas-carrying-bitcoins-dirty-baggage-idUSKBN2AA193\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">carbon dioxide emissions<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> of a small, developing nation like Sri Lanka or Jordan. Jordan, in particular, is home to <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/data.worldbank.org\/indicator\/SP.POP.TOTL?locations=JO\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">10 million people<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. It\u2019s impossible to say <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.jbs.cam.ac.uk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/08\/2017-04-20-global-cryptocurrency-benchmarking-study.pdf\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">how many people use bitcoin<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> every month, and they certainly use it less often than residents in Amman use Jordanian dinars. But <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/coinmetrics.io\/charts\/#assets=btc_left=AdrActCnt_zoom=1582934400000,1614470400000\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">CoinMetrics <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">data indicates more than 1 million bitcoin addresses are active, daily, out of up to <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/assets.ctfassets.net\/hfgyig42jimx\/5u8QqK4lqjEgL506mOx4m3\/d44d8e204aecfc75a839e2a9d505f5d1\/Crypto.com_Data_Report_-_On-chain_Market_Sizing.pdf\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">106 million <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">accounts active in the past decade, as tallied by the exchange Crypto.com.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ue6l7mtWMk\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/08\/teslas-bitcoin-investment-could-be-bad-for-the-companys-climate-reputation-and-its-bottom-line\/\">Tesla&#8217;s Bitcoin investment could be bad for the company&#8217;s climate reputation and its bottom line<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Tesla&#8217;s Bitcoin investment could be bad for the company&#8217;s climate reputation and its bottom line&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/08\/teslas-bitcoin-investment-could-be-bad-for-the-companys-climate-reputation-and-its-bottom-line\/embed\/#?secret=ue6l7mtWMk\" data-secret=\"ue6l7mtWMk\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201c<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">We get the total population of unique bitcoin (BTC) and ether (ETH) users by counting the total number of addresses from listed exchanges, subtracting addresses owned by the same users on multiple exchanges,\u201d said a Crypto.com spokesperson. \u201cWe then further reduce this number by accounting for users who own both ETH and BTC.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">That\u2019s a lot of people using these financial networks. Plus, many bitcoin mining businesses rely on environmentally friendly energy sources like hydropower and capturing natural gas leaks from oil fields. A mining industry veteran, Compass Mining COO Thomas Heller, said Chinese hydropower mines in Sichuan and Yunnan get cheaper electricity during the wet season. They continue to use hydropower all year, he added, although it\u2019s less profitable during the annual dry season.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cThe electricity price outside of May to October [wet season] is much more expensive,\u201d Heller said. \u201cHowever, some farms do have water supply in other parts of the year.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--left\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tThe best way to make cryptocurrency mining more eco-friendly is to support lawmakers that want to encourage mining in regions that already have underutilized energy sources.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Basically, cryptocurrency mining doesn\u2019t inherently produce extra carbon emissions because computers can use power from any source. In 2019, the digital asset investing firm CoinShares released a study estimating up to <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/coinshares.com\/research\/bitcoin-mining-network-december-2019\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">73%<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u00a0of bitcoin miners use at least some renewable energy as part of their power supply, including <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/chinese-city-known-for-bitcoin-mining-seeks-blockchain-firms-to-burn-excess-hydropower\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">hydropower<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> from China\u2019s massive dams. All of the top five <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/btc.com\/stats\/pool\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">bitcoin mining pools<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, consortiums for miners to cooperate for better profit margins, rely heavily on hydropower. This statistic doesn\u2019t impress de Vries, who pointed out that Cambridge researchers found renewable energy makes up <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.jbs.cam.ac.uk\/faculty-research\/centres\/alternative-finance\/publications\/3rd-global-cryptoasset-benchmarking-study\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">39%<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u00a0of miners&#8217; total energy consumption.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cI put one solar panel on my power plant, I also have a mixture of renewable energy,\u201d de Vries said.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In terms of geographic distribution, Cambridge data indicates Chinese bitcoin mining operations represent around <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/cbeci.org\/mining_map\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">65% <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">of the network\u2019s power, called hashrate. In some regions, like China\u2019s <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2021-02-09\/tesla-s-bitcoin-binge-spells-overtime-for-xinjiang-coal-miners\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Xinjiang province<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, bitcoin miners also burn coal for electricity. Beyond cryptocurrency mining, this province is known for human rights abuses against the <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.bbc.com\/news\/world-asia-china-22278037\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Uighur population<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, which China is violently suppressing as part of a <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/world\/2015\/oct\/01\/at-least-50-reported-dead-in-september-attack-as-china-celebrates-xinjiang\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">broader struggle<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> to capitalize on the region\u2019s <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2014\/12\/21\/world\/asia\/china-invests-in-xinjiang-region-rich-in-oil-coal-and-also-strife.html\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">natural resources<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. When <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/qz.com\/1978807\/bitcoin-has-a-xinjiang-problem\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">critics<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> sound the alarm about cryptocurrency mining and energy consumption, this is often the dynamic they\u2019re concerned about.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">On the other hand, North American miners make up roughly <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/cbeci.org\/mining_map\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">8%<\/span><\/a>\u00a0<span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">of the <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/how-bitcoins-price-slump-is-changing-the-geography-of-mining\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">global hashrate<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, followed closely by miners in Russia, Kazakhstan, Malaysia and <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/cheap-power-lures-crypto-miners-to-iran-but-its-not-as-easy-as-it-sounds\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Iran<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani called for the creation of a <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/rouhani-bitcoin-mining-iran\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">national bitcoin mining strategy<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> in 2020, aiming to grow the Islamic nation\u2019s influence over this financial system despite <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/iranian-general-advocates-crypto-use-for-skirting-sanctions-report\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">banking sanctions<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> imposed by the United States.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Wherever nations and organizations offer the most profitable <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/decrypt.co\/39718\/bitcoin-miners-in-china-lose-access-to-cheap-electricity\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">mining regulations<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, those are the places where bitcoin mining will proliferate. Chinese dominance, to date, can be at least partially attributed to <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.cato.org\/commentary\/chinas-mining-subsidies-create-tension-free-trade-rules\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">government subsidies<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> for the mining industry. As such, nations like <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/qz.com\/1172632\/chinas-dominance-in-bitcoin-mining-under-threat-as-regulators-hit-where-it-hurts-electricity\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">China<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2020-12-27\/bitcoin-miners-in-nordic-region-get-a-boost-from-cheap-power\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Norway<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> offer subsidies that incentivize bitcoin miners to use local hydropower sources.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As the<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.seetee.io\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> Seetee research report <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">by <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/aker-bitcoin\/norways-aker-asa-sets-up-bitcoin-unit-idUSL1N2L60AE\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Aker ASA<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, a $6 billion public company based in Norway, said: \u201cThe financiers of min\u00ading op\u00ader\u00ada\u00adtions will in\u00adsist on us\u00ading the cheap\u00adest en\u00ader\u00adgy and so by de\u00adf\u00adi\u00adn\u00adi\u00adtion it will be elec\u00adtric\u00adi\u00adty that has no bet\u00adter eco\u00adnom\u00adic use.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The best way to make cryptocurrency mining more eco-friendly is to support lawmakers that want to encourage mining in regions that already have underutilized energy sources.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When it comes to North America, Blockstream CEO Adam Back says his company\u2019s mining facilities, with <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/blockstream-microbt-bitcoin-mining\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">300 megawatts <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">in mining capacity, rely on a mix of industrial power sources like hydropower. He added Blockstream is exploring solar-powered bitcoin mining options as a sort of \u201cretirement home\u201d for outdated machines.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cWith solar energy, if you\u2019re only online 50% of the time, that\u2019s something to consider in terms of the cost analysis,\u201d Back said. \u201cThat\u2019s a better option for older machines, after you\u2019ve already recouped the costs of the equipment.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Due to surging cryptocurrency prices, there\u2019s now a <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/us-crypto-currency-china-mining\/global-chip-shortage-hits-chinas-bitcoin-mining-sector-idUSKBN29R1AY\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">global shortage<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> of bitcoin mining equipment, Back added, with demand outpacing supply and production taking up to six months per machine. Emma Todd, founder of the consultancy MMH Blockchain Group, said the shortage is driving up the price of mining machines.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cFor example, a Bitmain Antminer S9 mining machine that used to cost $35 &#8211; $55 in July 2020 on the secondary market, now costs about $275 &#8211; $300,\u201d Todd said. \u201cThis means that most, if not all mining companies looking to purchase new or secondary equipment, are all experiencing the same challenges. As a result of the global chip shortage, most new mining equipment that is scheduled to come out in the next few months, will almost certainly be delayed.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"DBgA0mJSH3\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/24\/how-emerging-markets-are-approaching-crypto\/\">How emerging markets are approaching crypto<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;How emerging markets are approaching crypto&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/24\/how-emerging-markets-are-approaching-crypto\/embed\/#?secret=DBgA0mJSH3\" data-secret=\"DBgA0mJSH3\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Critics like de Vries point out that, due to market forces, industrial miners are unlikely to reduce their power consumption with new machines, which are more efficient.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cIf you have more efficient machines but earn the same money, then people just run two machines instead of one,\u201d de Vries said.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">And yet, because cryptocurrency prices are rising faster than new miners can be constructed, Back said \u201cretiring\u201d old machines with renewable energy sources becomes more profitable than simply abandoning them for new equipment. In addition, Back said, <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2020-09-01\/bitcoin-miner-is-scoring-700-profits-selling-energy-to-grid\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">robust bitcoin mining infrastructure<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> can <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coincenter.org\/how-bitcoin-could-drive-the-clean-energy-revolution\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">support communities <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">rather than draining resources. This is because bitcoin miners can help <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/christopherhelman\/2020\/05\/21\/how-this-billionaire-backed-crypto-startup-gets-paid-to-not-mine-bitcoin\/?sh=14ac8ae37596\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">store and arbitrage<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> energy flows.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cYou can turn miners on and off if you get to a surge prices situation, you can use the power for people to heat their homes if that\u2019s more urgent or more profitable,\u201d Back said. \u201cBitcoin could actually support power grids.\u201d\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Meanwhile, just north of the Canadian border, Upstream Data president Steve Barbour said a growing number of traditional oil and gas companies are quietly ramping up their own bitcoin mining operations.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--left\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tThis puts the bitcoin economy on par with the carbon dioxide emissions of a small, developing nation like Sri Lanka or Jordan.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201c<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Right now it\u2019s <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/AnitaPosch\/status\/1364915550032457732\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">hydro<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and coal. That\u2019s the majority of the big industrial mining. But on the global scale, that\u2019s going to shift more toward any cheap power, including natural gas,\u201d Barbour said. \u201c<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Oil fields already have cheap energy with the venting flares, the waste gas, there\u2019s potential for approximately 160 gigawatts [of mining power] this year.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Upstream Data helps oil companies set up and operate bitcoin miners in a way that captures waste and low quality gas, which they couldn\u2019t sell before, totaling 100 deployments across North America. These companies rarely go public with their bitcoin mining operations, Barbour said, because they\u2019re concerned about attracting negative press from Bitcoin critics.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cThey are definitely concerned about reputational risk, but I think that\u2019s going to change soon because you have big, credible companies like Tesla involved with Bitcoin,\u201d Barbour said.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Even within the cryptocurrency industry, there are many people who dislike how power-intensive bitcoin mining is and are experimenting with different mining methods. For example, the Ethereum community is trying to switch to a \u201c<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/09\/02\/the-collapse-of-eth-is-inevitable\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">proof-of-stake<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201d (PoS) mining model, powering the network with locked up coins instead of Bitcoin\u2019s intensive \u201cproof-of-work\u201d (PoW) model.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"hj2r8j3R5p\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/17\/is-rising-usage-driving-cryptos-recent-price-boom\/\">Is rising usage driving crypto&#8217;s recent price boom?<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Is rising usage driving crypto&#8217;s recent price boom?&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/17\/is-rising-usage-driving-cryptos-recent-price-boom\/embed\/#?secret=hj2r8j3R5p\" data-secret=\"hj2r8j3R5p\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As the name might suggest, PoW requires a lot of computational \u201cwork.\u201d That\u2019s what miners do, lots and lots of math problems that are so difficult the computers require a lot of electricity. With regards to Ethereum, which currently runs on PoW but will theoretically run on PoS in a few years, there are<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/etherscan.io\/chart\/active-address\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> hundreds of thousands <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">of <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/coinmetrics.io\/charts\/#assets=btc,eth_left=AdrActCnt_zoom=1279411200000,1614470400000\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">daily active addresses<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, sometimes half as many as Bitcoin. Like Bitcoin, a few industrial mining projects with facilities in China generate more than half of the <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/etherscan.io\/stat\/miner?range=7&amp;blocktype=blocks\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ethereum network\u2019s power.<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> Each Ethereum transaction requires nearly as much energy as <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/digiconomist.net\/ethereum-energy-consumption\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">two American households <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">use per day.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cWhat I like about the Ethereum community is at least they are thinking about how to solve the problem,\u201d de Vries said. \u201cWhat I don\u2019t like is they\u2019ve been talking about it for a few years and haven\u2019t been able to actually do it.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Ethereum ecosystem uses enough energy every year to power the nation of <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/digiconomist.net\/ethereum-energy-consumption\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Panama<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. Like Bitcoin, each Ethereum transaction costs enough for <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/blog.trezor.io\/three-myths-about-bitcoins-energy-consumption-ef613a1f3d5\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">electricity costs <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">that the money could also buy a nice lunch. Both of these networks require enough power to fuel small countries, although Ethereum usually has <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/ethereum-activity-metric-hit-highest-level-for-2-years\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">less than half <\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">of the million daily users that Bitcoin has. It\u2019s clear cryptocurrency transactions require more power than Visa transactions. However, a cryptocurrency isn\u2019t just a payments company. It is a whole currency system.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If the bitcoin market cap were ranked as a country, by the <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/decrypt.co\/39425\/bitcoin-is-now-the-5th-largest-world-currency\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">value of the money supply<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, Bitcoin would come in fifth place behind Japan. And that\u2019s not even considering adjacent ecosystems like Ethereum. In short, power consumption in the global Bitcoin economy is comparable to that of some other industrialized financial systems. It is inefficient, as de Vries points out, as are many of the systems used in emerging economies. Out of millions of users, <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.jbs.cam.ac.uk\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/08\/2017-04-20-global-cryptocurrency-benchmarking-study.pdf\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">thousands<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> of people <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/what-its-really-like-to-live-on-bitcoin-in-the-middle-east\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">around the world<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> rely on <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.vice.com\/en\/article\/pkd83y\/people-are-spending-millions-on-jpegs-tweets-and-other-crypto-collectibles\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">cryptocurrency for income<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. They are generally optimistic about the <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/24\/how-emerging-markets-are-approaching-crypto\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">cryptocurrency ecosystem<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, believing it will become more efficient as the technology matures.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cI see Bitcoin mining increasingly playing a role in the transition to a clean, modern and more decentralized energy system,\u201d said one such Canadian business consultant, Magdalena Gronowska. \u201cMiners can provide grid balancing and flexible demand-response services and improve renewables integration.\u201d<\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u00a0\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p>&nbsp;<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Energy consumption has become the latest flashpoint for cryptocurrency. Critics decry it as an energy hog while proponents hail it for being less intensive than the current global economy.\u00a0 One such critic, DigiEconomist founder Alex de Vries, said he\u2019s \u201cnever seen anything that is as inefficient as bitcoin.\u201d\u00a0 On the other side of the debate, [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":84837756,"featured_media":1583823,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"abff6484-26f5-346e-bfd3-28f62bd3ecac"},"categories":[576601119],"tags":[576863416],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/01\/bitcoin-mining.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3lItnq3","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":false,"premiumCutoffPercent":1,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[2093616],"hide_featured_image":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2127248"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2127248"}],"version-history":[{"count":0,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2127248\/revisions"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/guest-authors\/leigh-cuen"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2127248&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/84837756"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/1583823"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media?parent=2127248"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories?post=2127248"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddab
