Crunch: Facebook shows off a wrist-based interface"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Facebook develops a new way to interact with AR, Uber&#8217;s facial recognition policy faces scrutiny and SpaceX&#8217;s Starship rocket booster hits a major milestone. This is your Daily Crunch for March 19, 2021.<\/p>\n<p><strong>The big story: Facebook shows off wrist-based interface<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>This project comes out of Facebook Reality Labs and is supposed to present <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/facebook-showcases-wrist-worn-ar-interface-concept\/\">an alternative computer interface on your wrist<\/a>, with electromyography sensors to interpret motor nerve signals.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>In a blog post, Facebook said a wrist-based device &#8220;could reasonably fit into everyday life and social contexts,&#8221; while allowing the company to &#8220;bring the rich control capabilities of your hands into AR, enabling intuitive, powerful and satisfying interaction.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Facebook identifies this as a research prototype, so don&#8217;t expect it to turn into a commercial product anytime soon. But it&#8217;s still suggestive, particularly given the company&#8217;s sometimes-surprising hardware strategy and rumors that it might be working on an Apple Watch competitor.<\/p>\n<p><strong>The tech giants<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/india-tells-court-to-block-whatsapps-policy-update-says-new-change-violates-laws\/\">India asks court to block WhatsApp\u2019s policy update, says new change violates laws<\/a> \u2014 The Indian government alleged on Friday that WhatsApp\u2019s planned privacy update violates local laws on several counts.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/uber-under-pressure-over-facial-recognition-checks-for-drivers\/\">Uber under pressure over facial recognition checks for drivers<\/a> \u2014 Uber\u2019s use of facial recognition technology for a driver identity system is being challenged in the U.K.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/instagram-whatsapp-down\/\">Instagram and WhatsApp hit by outage<\/a> \u2014\u00a0The outage began around 1:40 p.m. ET and lasted for more than half an hour.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Startups, funding and venture capital<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><a booster for Starship<\/a> \u2014\u00a0SpaceX has completed what\u2019s known as the \u201cstacking\u201d of its first Super Heavy prototype.<\/p>\n<p><a seal of approval for its equipment monitoring tech<\/a> \u2014\u00a0Throughout their lives, the founders had heard their parents complain about the sorry state of maintenance and heavy equipment in their factories.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/superpedestrian-positions-itself-as-the-go-to-partner-for-cities-with-new-e-scooter-safety-upgrades\/\">Superpedestrian positions itself as the go-to partner for cities with new e-scooter safety upgrades<\/a> \u2014\u00a0Superpedestrian is considered an up-and-coming player in the micromobility world because of how it handles safety issues.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Advice and analysis from Extra Crunch<\/strong><\/p>\n<p><a lection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=3457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=3457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=3457"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":961220,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/daily-crunch\/","name":"Daily Crunch","slug":"daily-crunch","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/961220"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=961220"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":81819,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/facebook\/","name":"Facebook","slug":"facebook","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/81819"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=81819"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2125265,"date":"2021-03-19T14:48:29","date_gmt":"2021-03-19T21:48:29","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2125265"},"modified":"2021-03-19T11:19:17","modified_gmt":"2021-03-19T18:19:17","slug":"deep-science-ai-is-in-the-air-water-soil-and-steel","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/deep-science-ai-is-in-the-air-water-soil-and-steel\/","title":{"rendered":"Deep science: AI is in the air, water, soil and steel"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Research papers come<\/span> out far too rapidly for anyone to read them all, especially in the field of machine learning, which now affects (and produces papers in) practically every industry and company. This column aims to collect some of the most relevant recent discoveries and papers \u2014 particularly in but not limited to artificial intelligence \u2014 and explain why they matter.<\/p>\n<p>This week brings a few unusual applications of or developments in machine learning, as well as a particularly unusual rejection of the method for pandemic-related analysis.<\/p>\n<p>One hardly expects to find machine learning in the domain of government regulation, if only because one assumes federal regulators are hopelessly behind the times when it comes to this sort of thing. So it may surprise you that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has partnered with researchers at Stanford to<a href=\"https:\/\/news.stanford.edu\/2021\/03\/08\/assessing-regulatory-fairness-machine-learning\/\"> algorithmically root out violators of environmental rules<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>When you see the scope of the issue, it makes sense. EPA authorities need to process millions of permits and observations pertaining to Clean Water Act compliance, things such as self-reported amounts of pollutants from various industries and independent reports from labs and field teams. The Stanford-designed process sorted through these to isolate patterns like which types of plants, in which areas, were most likely to affect which demographics. For instance, wastewater treatment in urban peripheries may tend to underreport pollution and put communities of color at risk.<\/p>\n<p><span class=\"embed-youtube embed breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"><iframe class='youtube-player' width='640' height='360' src='https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/Pj4xD71NMX8?version=3&#038;rel=1&#038;showsearch=0&#038;showinfo=1&#038;iv_load_policy=1&#038;fs=1&#038;hl=en-US&#038;autohide=2&#038;wmode=transparent' allowfullscreen='true' style='border:0;' sandbox='allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation'><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n<p>The very process of reducing the compliance question to something that can be computationally parsed and compared helped clarify the agency&#8217;s priorities, showing that while the technique could identify more permit holders with small violations, it may draw attention away from general permit types that act as a fig leaf for multiple large violators.<\/p>\n<p>Another large source of waste and expense is processing scrap metal. Tons of it goes through sorting and recycling centers, where the work is still mostly done by humans, and as you might imagine, it&#8217;s a dangerous and dull job. <a href=\"https:\/\/earthryse.prowly.com\/130625-eversteel-ai-based-image-recognition-technology-for-sorting-steel-scraps\">Eversteel is a startup out of the University of Tokyo<\/a> that aims to automate the process so that a large proportion of the work can be done before human workers even step in.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2126624\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2126624\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2126624\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg\" alt=\"Image of scrap metal with AI-detected labels for various kinds of items overlaid.\" width=\"1024\" height=\"512\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg 2170w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg?resize=150,75 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg?resize=300,150 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg?resize=768,384 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg?resize=680,340 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg?resize=1536,767 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg?resize=2048,1023 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/impurity_detection.jpg?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2126624\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Eversteel<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Eversteel uses a computer vision system to classify incoming scrap into nearly two dozen categories, and to flag impure (i.e., an unrecyclable alloy) or <a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=Yg-PDmfuha4\">anomalous items<\/a> for removal. It&#8217;s still at an early stage, but the industry isn&#8217;t going anywhere, and the lack of any large data set for training their models (they had to make their own, informed by steelworkers and imagery) showed Eversteel that this was indeed virgin territory for AI. With luck, they&#8217;ll be able to commercialize their system and attract the funding they need to break into this large but tech-starved industry.<\/p>\n<p>Another unusual but potentially helpful application of computer vision is in soil monitoring, a task every farmer has to do regularly to monitor water and nutrient levels. When they do manage to automate it, it&#8217;s done in a rather heavy-handed way. A team from the University of South Australia and Middle Technical University in Baghdad show that the sensors, hardware and thermal cameras used now may be overkill.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2126556\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2126556\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2126556\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg\" alt=\"Buckets of soil shown under various lights.\" width=\"1024\" height=\"676\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg 2370w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg?resize=150,99 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg?resize=300,198 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg?resize=768,507 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg?resize=680,449 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg?resize=1536,1014 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg?resize=2048,1352 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/soil-cv.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2126556\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> UNISA\/Middle Technical University<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Surprisingly, their answer is a standard RGB digital camera, which analyzes the color of the soil to estimate moisture. &#8220;We tested it at different distances, times and illumination levels, and the system was very accurate,&#8221; said Ali Al-Naji, one of the creators. It could (and is planned to) be used to make a cheap but effective smart irrigation system that could improve crop yield for those who can&#8217;t afford industry-standard systems.<div Crunch roundup: AI eats fintech, fundraising visas, no-code transition tips, more"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Most American retail<\/span> banks are designed the same way: Customers must pass several desks set aside for loan and mortgage officers before they can talk to a customer representative.<\/p>\n<p>I only step inside a bank a few times each year, but even pre-pandemic, I can&#8217;t remember the last time I saw someone sitting at one of those desks. Everyone I know who&#8217;s obtained a home or business loan in the recent past started with an online application process.<\/p>\n<p>For <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/ai-fintech-products-are-operating-at-scale-and-investor-interest-is-maturing\/\">this morning&#8217;s column<\/a>, Alex Wilhelm interviewed Dave Girouard, CEO of Upstart, an AI-powered fintech lender that expects to see growth increase 114% this year.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>A forecast like that suggests that retail banks have gotten comfortable with using automated tools to calculate risk, which may help explain all the empty desks at my local branch.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;If Upstart hits its 2021 numbers, we will be able to read into them broader adoption of AI among old-guard firms,&#8221; says Alex.<\/p>\n<p>According to PitchBook, investors are also more bullish on AI: Q4 2020 saw record funding for AI and ML startups, and exit totals are increasing as well.<\/p>\n<p>I wouldn&#8217;t mind adding a gently used desk to my home office; perhaps I should call my bank and see if they have one to spare.<\/p>\n<p>Thanks very much for reading Extra Crunch. class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Yuichiro Chino \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Why are developers still solving everyday pain points with manual, archaic processes, as opposed to employing \u201cLittle AI\u201d?<\/p>\n<p>There are millions of everyday use cases for AI, where technology is empowered to learn and decide on a course of action that offers the best outcome for consumers and companies alike.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"H49mGDR1fO\"><p><a driven in part by the pandemic\u2019s economic impact, is showing no sign of abating.<\/p>\n<p>Many employers are failing to identify viable job candidates, much less interviewing or hiring them. What\u2019s holding them back?<\/p>\n<p>Often, it&#8217;s a poorly drafted job posting.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"5qcdR7rrHg\"><p><a class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Korrawin \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>No-code is changing how organizations build and maintain applications.<\/p>\n<p>It democratizes application development by creating \u201ccitizen developers\u201d who can quickly build out apps that meet their business-facing needs in real time, realigning IT and business objectives by bringing them closer together.<\/p>\n<p>How can your company get ahead of the trend?<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"c7VRbxS042\"><p><a class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> jokerpro \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The idiosyncrasies of sales taxes are a burden on small- and medium-sized businesses, but a new legion of startups is emerging to help companies manage the intricacies of cross-jurisdictional taxes.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>Snowflake gave up its dual-class shares: Should you?<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2126634\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> VectorInspiration \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Some founders and investors argue that these preferred shares protect them from the whims of the market, but the perspective isn\u2019t universally accepted.<\/p>\n<p>Dual-class shares are a controversial governance structure, and some wonder if they are setting up an unfair playing field by allowing a cabal to wield outsized power.<\/p>\n<p>So why would Snowflake give up such a powerful tool?<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"k7UZuS5tNX\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/18\/snowflake-gave-up-its-dual-class-shares-should-you\/\">Snowflake gave up its dual-class shares. width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>MaaS transit: The business of mobility as a service<\/h2>\n<p><div class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Bryce Durbin<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>As transit agencies seek to win back riders, a flurry of platforms \u2014 some backed by giants like Uber, Intel and BMW \u2014 are offering new technology partnerships.<\/p>\n<p>Whether it\u2019s bundling bookings, payments or just trip planning, startups are selling these mobility-as-a-service (MaaS) offerings as a lifeline to make transit agencies the backbone of urban mobility.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"x8yauIXSAp\"><p><a One thing that points to?<\/p>\n<p>Trading platforms are being valued like high-margin video games.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nigelsussman.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nigel Sussman <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">(opens in a new window)<\/span><\/a><\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>I knew African founders lacked the same access to capital as entrepreneurs based in Europe or the United States, but the numbers are far less favorable than I thought.<\/p>\n<p>According to Dauda Barry, CEO of Adaplay Esports, African startups have raised $500 million so far in 2021. If that trend continues, he estimates that the region&#8217;s tech companies will exceed the $1.4 billion they raised in 2020.<\/p>\n<p>For perspective: &#8220;Stripe raised more yesterday than Barry had reported for the entire African continent this year,&#8221; Alex Wilhelm noted in today&#8217;s column.<\/p>\n<p>Digging deeper, he pulled numbers from Crunchbase and PitchBook to track VC activity in Africa over the last three months. Once he filtered private equity funding from nonequity investments, the numbers were &#8220;staggering.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;I am surprised that more VCs aren\u2019t investing in Africa,&#8221; says Alex. &#8220;It smells like investing arbitrage.&#8221;<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"HHxNH7Dimr\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/16\/the-global-inequity-in-venture-financing-is-staggering\/\">The global inequity in venture financing is staggering<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;The global inequity in venture financing is width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>Farmland could be the next big asset class modernized by marketplace startups<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_1518394\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-1518394\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout USA&quot;\" width=\"1024\" height=\"683\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2017\/07\/gettyimages-185274428.jpg 2121w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2017\/07\/gettyimages-185274428.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2017\/07\/gettyimages-185274428.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-1518394\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> <a href=\"http:\/\/www.gettyimages.com\/search\/photographer?family=creative&amp;photographer=Pgiam\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Pgiam <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">(opens in a new window)<\/span><\/a> \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Companies that help farmers raise money for agricultural development projects are revolutionizing the way farm and forestland are acquired, developed and commercialized across the United States.<\/p>\n<p>While private equity has gotten a lot of press for expanding the size of their farmland investments, those investments are still dwarfed by the size of the potential farm industry in the U.S., meaning there\u2019s still plenty of opportunity for investors to provide additional capital.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"7g0xUhRDOd\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/16\/farmland-could-be-the-next-big-asset-class-modernized-by-marketplace-startups\/\">Farmland could be the next big asset class modernized by marketplace startups<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>The NFT market is just getting started, but where is it headed?<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2125368\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2125368\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2125368\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2125368\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/beeple_crap\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Beeple <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">(opens in a new window)<\/span><\/a> under a <a href=\"http:\/\/creativecommons.org\/licenses\/by\/4.0\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">CC BY 4.0 <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">(opens in a new window)<\/span><\/a> license.<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The crypto art craze might seem silly and expensive, but it could empower artists from emerging economies and underrepresented groups to access the global art market in ways that they couldn\u2019t before.<\/p>\n<p>Can it outlive the hype?<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"s92NVKPZ2C\"><p><a frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>Olo raises IPO range as DigitalOcean sees possible $5B debut valuation<\/h2>\n<p><div software company\u2019s rapid growth and profits. In the case of DigitalOcean, we have more work to do as its approach to growth is a bit different.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" markets<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_1996009\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-1996009\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout new window)<\/span><\/a><\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Stripe\u2019s $600 million round values the payments and banking software company at $95 billion, near the top end of the valuation range at which the company was said to be raising funds back in November 2020.<\/p>\n<p>Sadly, Stripe is still being coy with growth metrics. The Exchange digs in, no matter how vague.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"LDWA7KRyox\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/15\/stripes-epic-new-valuation-and-the-value-capture-gap-between-public-and-private-markets\/\">Stripe&#8217;s epic new valuation and the value-capture gap between public and private markets<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Stripe&#8217;s epic new valuation and the value-capture gap between public and private markets&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/15\/stripes-epic-new-valuation-and-the-value-capture-gap-between-public-and-private-markets\/embed\/#?secret=LDWA7KRyox\" data-secret=\"LDWA7KRyox\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>Julia Collins and Sarah Kunst outline how to build a fundraising process<\/h2>\n<p><img class=\"breakout aligncenter size-full wp-image-2123516\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/ECL-2021-03-10-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" \/><\/p>\n<p>Julia Collins, the first Black woman to co-found a venture-backed unicorn, and investor Sarah Kunst offer fundraising pointers on Extra Crunch Live.<\/p>\n<p>Kunst says good design is critical, but:<\/p>\n<p>If you\u2019re not a graphic designer, then any incremental minute that you\u2019re spending on trying to make your deck pretty is a waste of time. You need to be focusing on content. Hire somebody, pay them a tiny bit of money to be able to do a nice graphics pass on your deck, and it\u2019s going to make it a lot easier for people to to get the information that you need them to know.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"dmUNvnyfit\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/15\/julia-collins-and-sarah-kunst-outline-how-to-build-a-fundraising-process\/\">Julia Collins and Sarah Kunst outline how to build a fundraising process<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Julia Collins and Sarah Kunst outline how to build a fundraising process&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/15\/julia-collins-and-sarah-kunst-outline-how-to-build-a-fundraising-process\/embed\/#?secret=dmUNvnyfit\" data-secret=\"dmUNvnyfit\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>How nontechnical talent can break into deep tech<\/h2>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2124659\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2124659\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2124659\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"576\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg 2309w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg?resize=2048,1152 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-1226216285-1.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2124659\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Startup hiring processes can be opaque, and breaking into the deep tech world as a nontechnical person seems daunting. This column offers tactical advice for finding, reaching out to, cultivating relationships with and working at deep tech companies as a nontechnical candidate.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Most American retail banks are designed the same way: Customers must pass several desks set aside for loan and mortgage officers before they can talk to a customer representative. I only step inside a bank a few times each year, but even pre-pandemic, I can&#8217;t remember the last time I saw someone sitting at one /wp\/v2\/posts?categories=2401"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=2401"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=2401"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":35394854,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/venture-capital-2\/","name":"Venture Capital","slug":"venture-capital-2","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/35394854"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=35394854"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=35394854"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=35394854"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":576845204,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/extra-crunch-roundup\/","name":"Extra Crunch Roundup","slug":"extra-crunch-roundup","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576845204"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576845204"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576845204"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576845204"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576845204"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2127509,"date":"2021-03-19T14:32:00","date_gmt":"2021-03-19T21:32:00","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2127509"},"modified":"2021-03-21T10:20:41","modified_gmt":"2021-03-21T17:20:41","slug":"now-approved-in-la-abodus-backyard-homes-can-now-go-from-contract-to-completion-in-as-little-as-30-days","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/now-approved-in-la-abodus-backyard-homes-can-now-go-from-contract-to-completion-in-as-little-as-30-days\/","title":{"rendered":"Now approved in LA, Abodu&#8217;s backyard homes can now go from contract to completion in as little as 30 days"},"content":{"rendered":"<p dir=\"ltr\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.abodu.com\/\">Abodu<\/a>, one of a slew of startup companies pitching backyard homes and office spaces to Californians in an effort to help address the state&#8217;s housing shortage, has instituted a new &#8220;Quickship&#8221; program that can take an order from contract to construction and installation in about thirty days.<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">Behind the quick turnaround time is a pre-approval process that was first rolled out in San Jose, Calif. and came to Los Angeles in recent weeks.<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">Abodu began installing homes through a pre-approval process back in 2019, when the city of San Jose created a program that allowed developers of alternative dwelling units to submit plans for pre-approval to cut the time for homeowners.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">That approval process means that ADU developers like Abodu can be permitted in one hour. Other ADU developers pre-approved in San Jose, Calif. include <a href=\"https:\/\/actonadu.com\/\">Acton ADU<\/a>, the venture backed <a href=\"https:\/\/connect-homes.com\/\">Connect Homes<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.getadu.com\/\">J. Kretschmer Architect<\/a>, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.mayberryworkshop.com\/adu\">Mayberry Workshop<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.openremodel.com\/\">Open Remodel<\/a>, and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.prefabadu.com\/\">prefabADU<\/a>. In Los Angeles, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.mas.la\/project-selection-new\">La Mas<\/a>, IT House, Design, Bitches, Connect Homes, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.welcomeprojects.com\/\">Welcome Projects<\/a> and <a href=\"http:\/\/firstoff.net\/projects\/LA_ADU\/\">First Office<\/a> have all had homes pre-approved for construction.<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">Beyond the cities where Abodu&#8217;s ADUs have received pre-approval, the company has built across California in cities ranging from, Palo Alto, Millbrae, Orange County, to LA and Oakland. Units in the Bay Area cost roughly $189,000 as a starting price, compared to the $650,000 to $850,000 it takes to build units in a mid-rise apartment building, or $1 million per unit in a steel-reinforced highrise, according to the company.<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">\u201cOur Quickship program is the fastest way to add housing,\u201d said John Geary, CEO at Abodu.\u00a0 \u201cHomeowners with immediate needs, be it family situations or those looking for investment income, can now complete an ADU project in as little as four weeks. A key mission for Abodu is to make a serious dent in our state\u2019s housing deficit while providing people and municipalities the necessary blueprint to enact real change. \u201d<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">For Initialized partner (and former TechCrunch writer) Kim-Mai Cutler, who serves on the Abodu board of directors, the achievement of a 30 day construction milestone is almost a dream come true. Cutler <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2014\/04\/14\/sf-housing\/\">wrote the book (or the equivalent of a book)<\/a> on the housing crisis and its impact on the Bay Area and California broadly.<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">That piece led Cutler to work in public service &#8220;<span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">on boards and commissions <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/hsh.sfgov.org\/committees\/lhcb\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">overseeing the spending of federal dollars on homelessness<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.cityofberkeley.info\/Clerk\/Commissions\/Commissions__Measure_O_Bond_Oversight_Committee.aspx\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">the proceeds of municipal bonds directed at financing affordable housing<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> (<\/span><i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">because yes, for some segments of residents, you do have to explicitly subsidize housing at the local level.<\/span><\/i><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">),&#8221; as she noted in a blog post about her investment in\u00a0<\/span>Abodu.<\/p>\n<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><div id=\"attachment_2062908\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2062908\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2062908\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"768\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg 3600w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg?resize=150,113 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg?resize=300,225 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg?resize=768,576 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg?resize=680,510 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg?resize=1536,1152 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg?resize=2048,1536 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/DSF1364.jpg?resize=50,38 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2062908\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The interior of an Abodu home. Photo via Abodu.<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">Cutler backed the company because of her deep knowledge of the issues associated with housing.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#8220;The reason this is a big deal is because Northern California <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.mercurynews.com\/2019\/04\/25\/new-bay-area-crown-most-expensive-place-to-build-in-the-world\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">has been the most expensive and unpredictable place to build new housing in the world.<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> Projects typically take several years because of uncertainty with entitlements and materials,&#8221; Cutler wrote. &#8220;Over the past year, Abodu co-founders <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/johngeary93\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">John Geary<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/eric-mcinerney-37a9154a\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Eric McInerney<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> have put homes in the backyards of parents bringing kids home from college, a mother-and-son pair that each bought one for their homes in Millbrae, a couple looking to eventually house a grandmother in San Jose and on and on.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p>The key inspiration that Abodu&#8217;s founders hit on was their concentration on granny flats, casitas and backyard dwellings. &#8220;While deliberations over mid-rise density were stalling in Sacramento, the state legislature (and legislatures up north in the Pacific Northwest) were passing bill after bill, including Phil Ting&#8217;s AB 68 and Bob Wieckowski&#8217;s SB 1069, to make it really easy to add backyard units,&#8221; Cutler wrote. &#8220;This is the kind of change that suburban America wants, is comfortable with and can politically pass and implement easily.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p dir=\"ltr\">To Cutler&#8217;s thinking, Abodu&#8217;s 30 day construction schedule will change consumer behavior, thanks to the fact that the home can be craned in and installed in less than a day on a foundation constructed in less than two weeks. Its incredibly low cost will enable a lot of opportunities to develop new inventory and the simple fact is that inventory remains a scarce commodity. As Cutler noted, only <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2021\/02\/26\/upshot\/where-have-all-the-houses-gone.html\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">half as many homes are trading across the United States<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> as were available a year ago, which is happening at the same time as when millennials are entering prime family formation years.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ufJPpysIZb\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2014\/04\/14\/sf-housing\/\">How Burrowing Owls Lead To Vomiting Anarchists (Or SF&#8217;s Housing Crisis Explained)<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;How Burrowing Owls Lead To Vomiting Anarchists (Or SF&#8217;s Housing Crisis Explained)&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2014\/04\/14\/sf-housing\/embed\/#?secret=ufJPpysIZb\" data-secret=\"ufJPpysIZb\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Abodu, one of a slew of startup companies pitching backyard homes and office spaces to Californians in an effort to help address the state&#8217;s housing shortage, has instituted a new &#8220;Quickship&#8221; program that can take an order from contract to construction and installation in about thirty days. Behind the quick turnaround time is a pre-approval class=\"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tCharles Caldwell is VP of product management at <a href=\"https:\/\/www.logianalytics.com\/\">Logi Analytics<\/a>, which empowers the world\u2019s software teams with intuitive, developer-grade embedded analytics solutions. He has more than 20 years\u2019 experience in the analytics market, including 10+ years of direct customer implementation experience.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div><p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Organizations spend ungodly<\/span> amounts of money \u2014 millions of dollars \u2014 on business intelligence (BI) tools. Yet, adoption rates are still <a href=\"https:\/\/www.gartner.com\/en\/documents\/3753469\/survey-analysis-why-bi-and-analytics-adoption-remains-lo\">below 30%<\/a>. Why is this the case? Because BI has failed businesses.<\/p>\n<p>Logi Analytics\u2019 <a href=\"https:\/\/go.logianalytics.com\/report-hanover-2021-state-of-analytics.html?utm_medium=press-release&amp;utm_source=pr-newswire&amp;utm_campaign=hanover-1Q-why-users-demand-better\">2021 State of Analytics: Why Users Demand Better<\/a> survey showed that knowledge workers spend more than five hours a day in analytics, and more than 99% consider analytics very to extremely valuable when making critical decisions. Unfortunately, many are dissatisfied with their current tools due to the loss of productivity, multiple \u201csources of truth,\u201d and the lack of integration with their current tools and systems.<\/p>\n<p>\t<div class=\"article-block block--pullout block--left\">\n\t\t<blockquote>\n\t\t\tA gap exists between the functionalities provided by current BI and data discovery tools and what users want and need.\t\t\t\t\t<\/blockquote>\n\t<\/div>\n\t<\/p>\n<p>Throughout my career, I\u2019ve spoken with many executives who wonder why BI continues to fail them, especially when data discovery tools like Qlik and Tableau have gained such momentum. The reality is, these tools are great for a very limited set of use cases among a limited audience of users \u2014 and the adoption rates reflect that reality.<\/p>\n<p>Data discovery applications allow analysts to link with data sources and perform self-service analysis, but still come with major pitfalls. Lack of self-service customization, the inability to integrate into workflows with other applications, and an overall lack of flexibility seriously impacts the ability for most users (who aren\u2019t data analysts) to derive meaningful information from these tools.<\/p>\n<p>BI platforms and data discovery applications are supposed to launch insight into action, informing decisions at every level of the organization. But many are instead left with costly investments that actually create inefficiencies, hinder workflows and exclude the vast majority of employees who could benefit from those operational insights. Now that\u2019s what I like to call a lack of ROI.<\/p>\n<p>Business leaders across a variety of industries \u2014 including \u201clegacy\u201d sectors like manufacturing, healthcare and financial services \u2014 are demanding better and, in my opinion, they should have gotten it long ago.<\/p>\n<p>It\u2019s time to abandon BI \u2014 at least as we currently know it.<\/p>\n<p>Here\u2019s what I\u2019ve learned over the years about why traditional BI platforms and newer tools like data discovery applications fail and what I\u2019ve gathered from companies that moved away from them.<\/p>\n<h2><strong>The inefficiency breakdown is killing your company<\/strong><\/h2>\n<p>Traditional BI platforms and data discovery applications require users to exit their workflow to attempt data collection. And, as you can guess, stalling teams in the middle of their workflow creates massive inefficiencies. Instead of having the data you need to make a decision readily available to you, instead, you have to exit the application, enter another application, secure the data and then reenter the original application.<\/p>\n<p>According to the 2021 State of Analytics report, 99% of knowledge workers had to spend additional time searching for information they couldn\u2019t easily locate in their analytics solution.<div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Organizations spend ungodly amounts of money \u2014 millions of dollars \u2014 on business intelligence tools. Yet, adoption rates are still below 30%. Why is this the case? Because BI has failed businesses.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574430,"featured_media":2126849,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"357f3191-1b52-3bfc-be89-3126e31db0c0"},"categories":[25515,449557044,576605952,20429],"tags":[11453,50933,576846311,576849759,5812,4106781],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[576796357],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/GettyImages-156410688.jpg","shortlink":"https:\/\/tcrn.ch\/3cNQfjP","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"premiumContent":true,"premiumCutoffPercent":0.44,"featured":false,"subtitle":"","seoTitle":"","seoDescription":"","tc_cb_mapping":[],"associatedEvent":null,"event":null,"authors":[2126840],"hide_featured_image":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2126847"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/post"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2126847"}],"version-history":[{"count":6,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2126847\/revisions"}],"predecessor-version":[{"id":2127749,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts\/2126847\/revisions\/2127749"}],"authors":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/guest-authors\/charles-caldwell"}],"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/edit":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-admin\/post.php?post=2126847&action=edit"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574430"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/2126849"}],"wp:attachment":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrun technology","slug":"information-technology","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/5812"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=5812"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=5812"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=5812"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=5812"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":4106781,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/real-time-data\/","name":"real time data","slug":"real-time-data","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/4106781"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=4106781"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=4106781"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=4106781"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=4106781"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[{"id":576796357,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/extracrunch\/work\/","name":"Work","slug":"work","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796357"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796357"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2127724,"date":"2021-03-19T12:07:49","date_gmt":"2021-03-19T19:07:49","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2127724"},"modified":"2021-03-19T12:09:21","modified_gmt":"2021-03-19T19:09:21","slug":"facebook-showcases-wrist-worn-ar-interface-concept","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/facebook-showcases-wrist-worn-ar-interface-concept\/","title":{"rendered":"Facebook showcases wrist-worn AR interface concept"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Facebook\u2019s hardware strategy often looks pretty opaque from the outside. The company has done fairly well with Oculus sales amid pandemic demand. Even its Echo Show competitor Portal has seen a bump as people have been forced to socially distance. The company\u2019s smartphone partnership with HTC, meanwhile, fell flat eight or so years back.<\/p>\n<p>Earlier this year, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/facebook-plans-smartwatch-with-focus-on-messaging-health\">reports surfaced<\/a> that the company was working on its own Apple Watch competitor. The smartwatch was said to have a health focus, running on an open-source version of Android. That, of course, would mark an interesting alternative from Google\u2019s chosen wearOS.<\/p>\n<p>This week, the company highlighted <a href=\"https:\/\/about.fb.com\/news\/2021\/03\/inside-facebook-reality-labs-wrist-based-interaction-for-the-next-computing-platform\/\">another wrist-based wearable<\/a>. The specifics of the project don\u2019t line up super closely with earlier reports, which could well mean two separate projects. Facebook is a big company, after all.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden;\" src=\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/plugins\/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FTechAtFacebook%2Fvideos%2F1126949421469231%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=560\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"><\/iframe><\/p>\n<p>This particular project out of Facebook Reality Labs is more focused on providing an alternative computer interface. Specifically, it seems in line with the company\u2019s augmented reality efforts.<\/p>\n<p>Per yesterday\u2019s blog post:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>A separate device you could store in your pocket like a phone or a game controller adds a layer of friction between you and your environment. As we explored the possibilities, placing an input device at the wrist became the clear answer. The wrist is a traditional place to wear a watch, meaning it could reasonably fit into everyday life and social contexts. It\u2019s a comfortable location for all-day wear. It\u2019s located right next to the primary instruments you use to interact with the world \u2014 your hands. This proximity would allow us to bring the rich control capabilities of your hands into AR, enabling intuitive, powerful and satisfying interaction.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>I will say that, based on the information presented, this seems more conceptual. As in, this could be the key to offering more seamless control for some future augmented reality system. And even still, it\u2019s presented as a step on the way to a more deeply integrated human-computer solution. How deeply you want Facebook to integrate with your neurons is apparently a question we\u2019re all going to have to ask ourselves in the not too distant future.<\/p>\n<p><iframe style=\"border: none; overflow: hidden;\" src=\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/plugins\/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FTechAtFacebook%2Fvideos%2F1146186389155473%2F&amp;show_text=0&amp;width=560\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"><\/iframe><\/p>\n<p>This interface specifically is designed to use electromyography (EMG) sensors to interpret motor nerve signals and interact with the interface accordingly. The subject interestingly came up <a href=\"https:\/\/constine.substack.com\/p\/pressclub-with-mark-zuckerberg-daniel\">during a Clubhouse event<\/a> featuring Mark Zuckerberg last night. After Pebble founder\/YC partner Eric Migicovsky discussed experiences dealing with Apple for his own smartwatch startup, the Facebook CEO said the following:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>If you&#8217;re trying to build a watch, which we&#8217;re exploring as we talked about the wrist thing and I don&#8217;t want to call it a watch, but it&#8217;s the basic neural interfaces work that our Facebook reality labs team demoed some of our research about today. With the neural interface on the wrist, if you want that to integrate with the phone in any way, it&#8217;s just so much easier on Android than iOS. My guess is that this is an area where there probably should be a lot more focus. And I do think the private APIs are just something that makes it really difficult to have a healthy ecosystem.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>\u201cExploring\u201d seems like an operative word here. But it\u2019s always cool\/fascinating to see these projects in their early stages. Even if the promises might still seem a tad\u2026overzealous.<\/p>\n<p>EMG will eventually progress to richer controls. In AR, you\u2019ll be able to actually touch and move virtual UIs and objects, as you can see in this demo video. You\u2019ll also be able to control virtual objects at a distance. It\u2019s sort of like having a superpower like the Force.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"aWZcUonNsO\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/12\/will-apple-facebook-or-microsoft-be-the-future-of-augmented-reality\/\">Will Apple, Facebook or Microsoft be the future of augmented reality?<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Will Apple, Facebook or Microsoft be the future of augmented reality?&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/02\/12\/will-apple-facebook-or-microsoft-be-the-future-of-augmented-reality\/embed\/#?secret=aWZcUonNsO\" data-secret=\"aWZcUonNsO\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"IiUrheTwBZ\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/19\/week-in-review-facebook-hardware-finds-pandemic-market-fit\/\">Week in Review: Facebook hardware finds pandemic market fit<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Week in Review: Facebook hardware finds pandemic market fit&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/19\/week-in-review-facebook-hardware-finds-pandemic-market-fit\/embed\/#?secret=IiUrheTwBZ\" data-secret=\"IiUrheTwBZ\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>&nbsp;<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Facebook\u2019s hardware strategy often looks pretty opaque from the outside. The company has done fairly well with Oculus sales amid pandemic demand. Even its Echo Show competitor Portal has seen a bump as people have been forced to socially distance. The company\u2019s smartphone partnership with HTC, meanwhile, fell flat eight or so years back. Earlier :\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=3457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=3457"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=3457"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":38299,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/ar\/","name":"AR","slug":"ar","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/38299"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=38299"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=38299"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=38299"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=38299"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":282669,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/augmented-reality\/","name":"augmented reality","slug":"augmented-reality","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/282669"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=282669"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=282669"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=282669"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=282669"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":81819,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/facebook\/","name":"Facebook","slug":"facebook","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/81819"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=81819"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=81819"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":26895916,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/smartwatch\/","name":"smartwatch","slug":"smartwatch","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/26895916"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=26895916"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=26895916"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=26895916"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=26895916"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2127411,"date":"2021-03-19T12:01:46","date_gmt":"2021-03-19T19:01:46","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2127411"},"modified":"2021-03-19T12:28:15","modified_gmt":"2021-03-19T19:28:15","slug":"sidekick-browser-wants-to-be-a-productivity-honed-work-os-on-chromium","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/19\/sidekick-browser-wants-to-be-a-productivity-honed-work-os-on-chromium\/","title":{"rendered":"Sidekick Browser wants to be a productivity-honed &#8216;work OS&#8217; on Chromium"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The paradox of connected computing is how much information is made available to us in just a few clicks or taps &#8212; but also how this ocean of available data can overwhelm and lap over a particular bit of intel the moment we need to lay our fingers back on it.<\/p>\n<p>Fire up a web browser and it&#8217;s hard to deny it&#8217;s the best of times for knowledge work. Yet working across multiple browser tabs and windows can feel like the friction-filled, frustrating worst.<\/p>\n<p>This is the problem <a href=\"https:\/\/www.meetsidekick.com\">Sidekick Browser<\/a> is taking aim at by adding a productivity-focused layer atop Chromium that it bills as a &#8220;work OS&#8221;.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Multiple tab hell? Sidekick&#8217;s answer is to let you work from inside apps that live in the browser, rather than scattered across multiple windows and tabs.<\/p>\n<p>Apps like Slack and Skype and WhatsApp can be pinned in the sidebar in a vertical stack where you can easily find and switch between them. It also has support for multiple logins, granular notification controls and the ability to search across all these third-party apps (it offers &#8220;hundreds&#8221; currently but says users can add custom adds &#8220;which would function just like a bookmark&#8221;) right from the browser.<\/p>\n<p>And for all those tabs you open up every time you go down an internet browsing rabbit hole, Sidekick offers a Sessions feature that lets you save them as a collective bundle for easy filing away &#8212; with ofc the ability to reopen and revisit again at a later click.<\/p>\n<p>The built-in search also spans these Sessions so there&#8217;s no need to manually scroll back through the browser&#8217;s search history to try to track down where exactly it was you saw that reference to that randomly relevant bit of intel you breezed across one online day.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"2RnIl81BiG\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/03\/browsers-are-interesting-again\/\">Browsers are interesting again<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Browsers are interesting again&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/03\/browsers-are-interesting-again\/embed\/#?secret=2RnIl81BiG\" data-secret=\"2RnIl81BiG\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;Search across all your apps, tabs and workspaces in seconds,&#8221; is Sidekick&#8217;s alternative fix.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s also tackling productivity on the technical side &#8212; taking aim at browser-based lag with an &#8220;AI based tab suspension&#8221; feature that&#8217;s designed to improve on how Google&#8217;s Chrome browser hogs RAM by predicting which tabs the user is not going to use and dumping them from memory.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Sidekick is the fastest browser built especially for work,&#8221; is its elevator-pitchy promise.<\/p>\n<p>Collaboration is another core focus with features intended to help knowledge working teams be more productive as a unit; offering stuff like team role provisioning and custom workspaces to support different Session, app Sidebar and tabs set-ups, such as for a project or client.<\/p>\n<p>There&#8217;s also remote configuration tools for device security; a baked-in password manager for collaborative convenience to support teams needing to share passwords; and an embedded video chat platform so you can do team chats right from the exact same browser-based workspace you&#8217;re all using.<\/p>\n<p>Sidekick comes with its own ad blocker and anti-fingerprinting tech too &#8212; for a stated privacy purpose but also for an extra speed bump (i.e. via better page load times).<\/p>\n<p>Also on privacy, the startup&#8217;s very public promise is &#8220;we&#8217;ll never sell your data&#8221; (and it further specifies this includes &#8220;searches, browsing history, or any personal information&#8221;).<\/p>\n<p>The business model is SaaS and B2C for now, but Sidekick has designs on B2B &#8212; touting a pipeline of business-friendly features coming down the line.<\/p>\n<p>And &#8212; yes, before you ask &#8212; Chrome extensions are supported.<\/p>\n<p>Sidekick is announcing $2 million in seed funding led by KPCB &#8212; along with Remote First Capital and other angel investors.<\/p>\n<p>Founder Dmitry Pushkarev has played and won at the startup game before, in some very different areas &#8212; having founded a DNA sequencing company (Moleculo) back in 2011, which was quickly acquired by Illumina.<\/p>\n<p>Then in 2013 he left to found another business, ClusterK &#8212; focused on optimizing cloud computing resources across multiple cloud providers &#8212; which was acquired by Amazon in 2016, where Pushkarev stayed for a couple of years before getting the founder itch again.<\/p>\n<p>A stint as entrepreneur in residence (EIR) at Kleiner Perkins investigating the future of work was where the germ of the idea for Sidekick was born.<\/p>\n<p>The tool grabbed some early eyeballs a few months ago <a href=\"https:\/\/www.producthunt.com\/posts\/sidekick-browser\">via Product Hunt<\/a> &#8212; where Chris Messina was among its early fans, lauding the team for shaking up the browser space by combining &#8220;so many components that are essential to finding productivity as a modern knowledge worker!&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>Though Pushkarev was careful to course-correct Messina that it&#8217;s not building a full-fat browser to challenge Chrome itself (or any other internet browser).<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We do not intend to compete with browsers, they are a great choice for browsing,&#8221; he wrote. &#8220;Our goal is improve the browsing experience for work and productivity &#8212; something that, regretfully, browsers cannot do.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The San Francisco-based startup says it&#8217;s now being used by teams at companies including Microsoft, Dropbox, Slack and Lyft. It has around 30,000 users at this point a few months after its November 2020 launch, per Pushkarev, who says the team is mostly focused on product (&#8220;activation, retention, virality&#8221;) at this early stage.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The typical user is a knowledge worker &#8212; product managers, engineers, marketers, a fair number of students. Basically, prosumers who don&#8217;t just browse online, but do productive work and utilize communication tools,&#8221; he tells TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;During my EIR at KPCB, we thought a lot about the future of work, and one striking aspect of it is that today knowledge workers spend most of their time working in Browsers &#8212; a tool designed for Browsing,&#8221; he goes on, explaining the genesis of the idea for Sidekick.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;There are some important differences between how we browse and how we work, in particular &#8212; knowledge workers, spend more time working in web applications, with documents, using communications tools, accessing multiple accounts, and having to navigate a vast array of documents and projects. Unlike browsing &#8212; which is mostly search-based consumption of information.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Clearly, these are very different use cases, but companies who make browsers today have no ability to invest in making browser better for work due to their business model &#8212; they are paid by Google or Microsoft for searches, and any complication of the UX would mean that millions of users would turn to simpler browsers and they will lose search revenue.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We thought that it&#8217;s an unprecedented situation, where 200M professionals don\u2019t have access to professional tools, and that the industry is so heavily disincentivized to build those. As a result, we decided to change this and invent a new category of software &#8212; Browser for Work, or how we call it internally &#8212; a Work OS.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>So what type of work\/worker is Sidekick made for?\u00a0&#8220;Online work with Web applications, lots of documents, communication apps, multiple accounts, and different work streams. It&#8217;s designer for prosumers and wouldn&#8217;t be the best choice for just browsing &#8212; something that would be better served by other browsers,&#8221; he says.<\/p>\n<p>While the laser focus is work and productivity, Sidekick users can create multiple environments within the software &#8212; so could make other spaces more geared toward chilling out\/downtime, or other purposes than work too, for use at other times.<\/p>\n<p>While browsers do offer a variety of features like shortcuts and other elements aimed at increasing convenience, Pushkarev argues they simple can&#8217;t go as far as Sidekick intends to in honing a great work environment because their business model is too focused on search ads (in the case of Google Chrome) &#8212; or just because they need to be a more generalist tool for web browsing. Sidekick is therefore very much a &#8220;standalone business,&#8221; not just a nice set of enhancements any existing browser could make, in his view.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Unfortunately, extending other browsers is not a viable path here, one has to go deep inside Chrome codebase and re-think performance, memory optimization, security, support for multiple accounts, and privacy to build a comprehensive solution,&#8221; he says.<\/p>\n<p>One example of going above and beyond what a browser could or would do itself is the support it&#8217;s built for &#8220;hundreds&#8221; of third-party apps. &#8220;The reason we built this support is for better integrations &#8212; being able to display and control badges and notifications, integrate with our search, support multiple accounts and add helpful extensions,&#8221; he explains.<\/p>\n<p>He also points to the New Tab Page (shown in the feature image at the top of this post), which is due to launch for all users by the end of the month and which displays &#8220;all documents that work with organized according to type, with human-readable titles, and instant search across it&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Without deep integration with these apps we wouldn\u2019t be able to provide this experience and display barely usable browser history instead,&#8221; he notes.<\/p>\n<p>On the business model front, Pushkarev is confident that SaaS can work &#8212; and that Sidekick doesn&#8217;t have to monetize like other browsers do (i.e. &#8220;through data and searches&#8221;) &#8212; arguing:\u00a0&#8220;We are making a tool that saves hours to potentially millions of knowledge workers.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Another piece of the story is our <a href=\"https:\/\/www.meetsidekick.com\/how-it-works\">B2B business<\/a>, which we are building as we speak, but it&#8217;s still in early beta. In B2B, product browsers become a sort of company-provisioned remote workstations, that can be remotely configured and secured according to a role,&#8221; he adds.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;This is where the majority of our revenue comes from at the moment, but we are launching our first attempts at B2C monetization in March, by offering a subscription.&#8221;<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"bpfvaMX1wR\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/02\/everyone-has-an-opinion-on-the-27-7b-slack-acquisition\/\">Everyone has an opinion on the $27.7B Slack acquisition<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Everyone has an opinion on the $27.7B Slack acquisition&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/02\/everyone-has-an-opinion-on-the-27-7b-slack-acquisition\/embed\/#?secret=bpfvaMX1wR\" data-secret=\"bpfvaMX1wR\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Kp5SqYY8HT\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/29\/kpcb-has-already-blown-through-much-of-the-600-million-it-raised-last-year\/\">Kleiner Perkins has already blown through much of the $600 million it raised last year<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Kleiner Perkins has already blown through much of the $600 million it raised last year&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/29\/kpcb-has-already-blown-through-much-of-the-600-million-it-raised-last-year\/embed\/#?secret=Kp5SqYY8HT\" data-secret=\"Kp5SqYY8HT\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The paradox of connected computing is how much information is made available to us in just a few clicks or taps &#8212; but also how this ocean of available data can overwhelm and lap over a particular bit of intel the moment we need to lay our fingers back on it. Fire up a web Browser<\/p>\n"},"alt_text":"","media_type":"image","mime_type":"image\/jpeg","media_details":{"width":1280,"height":840,"file":"2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg","sizes":{"thumbnail":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=150,98","width":150,"height":98,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=150"},"medium":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=300,197","width":300,"height":197,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=300"},"medium_large":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=768,504","width":768,"height":504,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=1024"},"large":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=680,446","width":680,"height":446,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=680"},"guest-author-32":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=32,32","width":32,"height":32,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=32&h=32&crop=1"},"guest-author-50":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=50,50","width":50,"height":50,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=50&h=50&crop=1"},"guest-author-64":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=64,64","width":64,"height":64,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=64&h=64&crop=1"},"guest-author-96":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=96,96","width":96,"height":96,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=96&h=96&crop=1"},"guest-author-128":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=128,128","width":128,"height":128,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=128&h=128&crop=1"},"concierge-thumb":{"file":"sidekick.jpg?resize=50,33","width":50,"height":33,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg?w=50"},"full":{"file":"sidekick.jpg","width":1024,"height":672,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg"}},"image_meta":{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0","keywords":[]},"filesize":85930},"source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/sidekick.jpg","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/2127694"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/attachment"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2127694"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/39990176"}]}}],"wp:term":[[{"id":60523764,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/fundings-exits\/","name":"Fundings
